questions.answerB: Maintain a steady speed or accelerate gradually.
questions.answerC: Accelerate drastically.
questions.answerD: Not worry about your speed.
questions.explanation: Roll on the throttle through a turn to stabilize your suspension. Maintain a steady speed or accelerate gradually through the turn.

questions.question: What is often found in the center portion of the lane?
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Ice
questions.explanation: Drippings from cars tend to form an oily strip in the center of each lane. Unless conditions are wet, it is usually still safe for a motorcycle to operate on the center strip.

questions.question: When being passed, all of the following are potential hazards, except:
questions.answerB: Objects being thrown from other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blasts of wind.
questions.answerD: Headlights.
questions.explanation: When being passed, motorcyclists should be careful not to be hit by any part of the passing vehicle, including its mirrors. In addition to the vehicle itself, motorcyclists should be aware of wind gusts coming from the passing vehicle and potential objects being thrown by a passenger in the vehicle who may not be paying attention to the road.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever usually located?
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is usually located on the left handgrip.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: Do not change gears on railroad tracks because:
questions.answerC: Other drivers may not be expecting you to change gears.
questions.answerD: The uneven surface may make it more difficult to switch gears.
questions.explanation: It is best not to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks. There is a chance your motorcycle might stall while you are on the tracks.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not considered protective clothing?
questions.answerC: Long pants made of denim
questions.answerD: Athletic shoes
questions.explanation: In the event of a fall, a motorcyclist can receive protection from a leather jacket, long pants made of heavy denim, and full-fingered gloves. It is best for a motorcyclist to wear lace-up boots, high-top boots, or heavy shoes that support their ankles.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerC: Ride a little more slowly than usual.
questions.answerD: Ride a little faster than usual.
questions.explanation: Your motorcycle will sit lower than normal under the additional weight of a passenger. To accommodate, you should ride a bit more slowly than usual, particularly when riding through curves, through corners, or over bumps. The extra weight also means that your motorcycle will take longer than usual to speed up, slow down, or stop, so you should maintain a larger space cushion when carrying a passenger.

questions.question: If you are riding and your motorcycle starts to handle differently, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and check the tires.
questions.answerC: Pull over to check the chain.
questions.answerD: Pull over to check the windshield.
questions.explanation: A sudden change in handling may indicate that a tire on your motorcycle has failed. If you feel a change in the way your motorcycle handles, pull over safely and check your tires.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: Most crashes occur during the day. To lessen the chance of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerC: Not ride during the day.
questions.answerD: Look for safer routes.
questions.explanation: To minimize your chances of being in a crash, you should make yourself as visible as possible by wearing brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: When using a motorcycle with which you are unfamiliar, you should:
questions.answerA: Test the seat to make sure it is comfortable.
questions.answerB: Assume the motorcycle is in good riding condition.
questions.answerC: Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times before riding.
questions.answerD: Ride as you usually do, since most bikes are similar.
questions.explanation: Since all motorcycles are somewhat different, you should be very careful when using one that is new to you. Familiarize yourself with the motorcycle before setting off. Learn the gear pattern before riding by working the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders will rarely actually hear a tire going flat. Tire failure is more often indicated by a change in how the motorcycle handles.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: When riding, a cushion of space is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Give you space to react to hazards.
questions.answerC: Prevent you from avoiding hazards.
questions.answerD: Allow you to look at road signs.
questions.explanation: Allowing a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times will help ensure that you will have time to react if another driver makes a mistake. You will need the space to maneuver safely.

questions.question: When riding, goggles:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Are not as effective at protecting your eyes as eyeglasses.
questions.answerD: Are not effective in providing any protection.
questions.explanation: Goggles can provide protection for your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face. Eyeglasses are not an adequate substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: About ______ of accidents involve driver inattention?
questions.answerC: 60 percent
questions.answerD: 80 percent
questions.explanation: About 80 percent of traffic collisions involve some form of driver inattention.

questions.question: When riding in a group, you should:
questions.answerB: Place inexperienced riders at the back of the group.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Not tailgate other riders within the group.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, it is generally best to use a staggered formation. Use your mirrors periodically to check on riders behind you. Both the lead and sweep riders should be experienced motorcyclists who know group riding procedures well. Maintain proper space cushions within the group of riders.

questions.question: A linked braking system:
questions.answerA: Connects the front and rear brakes, applying both brakes when either brake lever is applied.
questions.answerB: Connects the front brake to the gear shifter, applying the brake when the rider downshifts.
questions.answerC: Connects the rear brake to a foot control.
questions.answerD: Connects the rear brake to a switch on the handlebar.
questions.explanation: A linked braking system connects the front and rear brakes on a motorcycle. This system applies braking pressure to both brakes when either the front or rear lever is used. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: Helmets are:
questions.answerB: Required for any operator who is under the age of 21 or who has held their license for less than a year.
questions.answerC: Required for all operators carrying passengers.
questions.answerD: Never required.
questions.explanation: In Rhode Island, motorcycle operators who are under the age of 21, or who have held their license for less than a year, must wear a helmet while riding. Helmets are recommended to all riders.

questions.question: Where is the front brake lever usually located?
questions.answerC: By the left foot peg
questions.answerD: By the right foot peg
questions.explanation: The front brake lever is generally located on the right handgrip. Make sure that you are aware of the locations of all your motorcycle's controls before beginning to ride.

questions.question: A motorcycle needs:
questions.answerA: Less frequent attention than a car.
questions.answerB: More frequent attention than a car.
questions.answerC: To have pre-ride checks performed only by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: To be serviced only at a dealer.
questions.explanation: Because a small technical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car, motorcycles need to be checked more frequently. Complete a thorough check before every ride.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: A leather jacket:
questions.answerA: Can make a rider look cool.
questions.answerB: Is usually too warm to wear when riding.
questions.answerC: Provides protection in a crash.
questions.answerD: Should not be worn when riding.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear a long-sleeved jacket, ideally made of leather, when riding. In warm weather, a leather jacket can help protect you against dehydration. Many motorcycle jackets are designed to help keep you cool even when the weather is hot.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks need to be consumed before a rider may begin to feel the effects?
questions.answerC: Six
questions.answerD: More than eight
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can affect a person's ability to ride. It is both illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Help you avoid other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid being seen by other drivers.
questions.answerD: Increase your ability to be seen by others.
questions.explanation: A well-chosen lane position should increase your ability to see and be seen and keep you out of other drivers' blind spots. It should help you avoid surface hazards, protect your lane from other drivers, communicate your intentions to others, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and offer you an escape route from any hazards that may arise.

questions.question: Riding at night:
questions.answerB: Is made safer by wearing reflective clothing.
questions.answerC: Is not safe because other drivers cannot see your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Should only be done in the city.
questions.explanation: You should wear reflective materials when riding at night to make yourself more visible to other road users.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerC: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Travel on the shoulder so you are not next to other traffic.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when braking is necessary, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be especially alert to oily areas, shaded areas, dirt, gravel, and bridges, as these surfaces may provide less traction than others.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerC: At the rear of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders behind them to keep an eye on them.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: If riding a three-wheel motorcycle in a group, you should travel in a:
questions.answerC: Single-file line.
questions.answerD: Row of pairs.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best for a group of two-wheeled motorcycles, three-wheeled motorcycles are too wide to allow this formation. A group of riders on three-wheeled motorcycles should travel in a single-file line.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerB: You will be slowing down suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals do not work.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's single brake light is not as noticeable as the two larger brake lights of a car or truck. It can be a good idea to flash your brake light to help others notice it, especially when you need to slow down more quickly than surrounding drivers may expect.

questions.question: A motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerB: Can tip over if making a turn too fast.
questions.answerC: Is designed to take corners at any speed.
questions.answerD: Should not be used for loading items.
questions.explanation: Even with three wheels on the ground, a sidecar can tip over if it is being turned too sharply or is moving too fast for a corner.

questions.question: The best source of information for your motorcycle is:
questions.answerC: Someone who has a different type of motorcycle.
questions.answerD: A television show about motorcycle riding.
questions.explanation: To be sure you are familiar with the specific type of motorcycle that you are planning to ride, read the owner's manual before riding it for the first time. This is particularly important if you are riding a borrowed motorcycle.

questions.question: In hot weather, wearing a riding jacket:
questions.answerA: Can help protect against heat exhaustion and dehydration.
questions.answerB: Is discouraged because it can cause heat-related problems.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the jacket is a light color.
questions.answerD: Is not important.
questions.explanation: A riding jacket and long pants should still be worn when riding in hot weather. In addition to their other safety benefits, they can protect a rider from heat exhaustion and dehydration.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: Any person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: In Rhode Island, a person of any age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If operating a three-wheeled motorcycle or riding with a sidecar, do not ride too far to the right of your lane because:
questions.answerA: Other drivers may not see you.
questions.answerB: You will not be able to pass other vehicles as easily.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may try to share your lane.
questions.answerD: You may run off the road.
questions.explanation: Because a sidecar sits on the right side of a motorcycle, riding too far to the right side of your lane risks the sidecar running off the road. Similarly, on a three-wheeled motorcycle, the rear right wheel may leave the road if you get too close to the right edge.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: At a minimum, how often should a motorcycle's hydraulic fluid be checked?
questions.answerC: Once a year
questions.answerD: Before every ride
questions.explanation: Pre-ride motorcycle inspections are an important part of ensuring safe riding. Hydraulic fluids and coolants should be checked at least once a week.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore them.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: Engine braking:
questions.answerB: Is slowing down by turning the engine off.
questions.answerC: Is slowing down by downshifting.
questions.answerD: Is not encouraged because of the damage it does to the engine.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the best protection for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerC: Wool
questions.answerD: Polyester
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants made of leather offer the greatest degree of protection to those riding motorcycles.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Can place you in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerB: Is better than riding behind the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is safe because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerD: Should only be done during the day.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding directly alongside another vehicle, since this may place you in the vehicle's blind spot. If the driver can't see you, they may enter your lane without warning. Riding alongside a vehicle is also dangerous because the vehicle will block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: If you wait an hour per alcoholic drink before you ride your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: If your front wheel begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged and ride out the skid.
questions.answerB: Keep the front brake engaged and release the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Immediately release and re-engage the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the front brake and increase the pressure on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the front brake immediately and completely before re-applying it smoothly.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator:
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: ______ is a guarantee that another driver sees you.
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle
questions.answerD: Nothing
questions.explanation: Nothing guarantees that a driver sees you. It is safest to assume that if another vehicle can enter your path, it will.

questions.question: If you think stopping your motorcycle will take longer than usual, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the road.
questions.answerD: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Lengthen your following distance when traveling on a slippery surface. If it will take longer than usual for your motorcycle to stop, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: Reflective material on your helmet:
questions.answerC: Should only be used at night.
questions.answerD: Does not help you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Reflective material on a vest or on the sides of your helmet can make you more visible to other drivers and should be used both day and night.

questions.question: Impairment from drinking alcohol occurs:
questions.answerC: Just above the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Well above the legal limit.
questions.explanation: It is never safe to operate a motorcycle after consuming any amount of alcohol. Impairment of the skills needed to safely ride begins well below the legal limit.

questions.question: Switching to a lower gear is also known as:
questions.answerC: Upshifting.
questions.answerD: Coasting.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear causes an effect similar to using the brakes. For this reason, downshifting is also known as engine braking.

questions.question: When riding under normal conditions, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least four seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking alcohol and wants to drive, which of the following should you not do?
questions.answerA: Encourage friends to talk them out of driving.
questions.answerC: Tell them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerD: Slow their pace of drinking.
questions.explanation: There are several strategies you can use to prevent someone from driving while under the influence of alcohol. You can arrange another way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow their pace of drinking, use any available excuse to stop them from leaving before they are sober, and get other friends involved to intervene as a group.
